. The peculiar circumstances connected
with the case of the Brig Crawford, which
will be developed in the sequel, induced
Chief Justice Marshall to hold special
term of the Federal Court for the Fifth Cir
cult and Eastern District Of Virginia, for the
trial Of the three Spaniards. The Court
was held On the 9Th ult., the most material
with. sses not being present, it was adjourn
ed from day to day, until their arrival from
New York. After they had arrived, four
indictments, one for Piracy and three for
Murder, were sent to the Grand Jury, who
after an examination into the testimony, re-
turned "a true bill" as to each. The three
prisoners, viz: Pepe, otherwise Joseph Hi
iario Cssaris, Couro, otherwise called Jos-
eph Miranda; and Felix, otherwise Felix
Barbeto were all charged in the first indict-
ment with Piracy, and in each of the others.
with the murder of some one OF the persons
who were slaughtered by them. The Court
was adjourned until the 10th, to give the
prisoners time to prepare their defence. The
prisoners having been arraigned pleaded
not guilty to all the indictments.-Mr. Stan
ard, District Attorney for the United States,
PIRACY AND MURDER.

The accompanying is translated from a
livelv description of the departure, for their
ultimate destination, of party OF those IN
dividuals, whom the laws Of France doom to
hard labo, or the galleys. They are from
time to time, turned over from the Courts
which have passed condemnation, to par
ticular iail, whence as soon as suiiicient
number have been gathered, they are sent
n narties. as the one here described, to sea-
norts. where they take the dress and heavy
irons they have to carry during the whoie
term prescribed by law. The former is a
red dress and cap, for those condemned tor
a tenn of wears; and red dress and green
can for the convict for life. Ibis account
heinp characteristic of national character,
under the most distressing circumstances,
and showing the effect of the French code OF
law. as contra distinguished from our own
penal laws, may not be uninteresting to the
philanthropst.


"Some days previeus, it had been amour
ced at Bcetre, that the departure OF the gal
lev slaves, for their respective destinations
would soon take place. At III O'Clock on
Monday, the news was confirmed. those
who were to compose the gang were accord
inpIy assembled together. They descended
ed from their chambers into yard at the
furthest end of the establishment. There was
in readiness the travelling apparel. which
is made of coarse raw linen. Each Of
those designated took his own. Agree ably
To the prison regulations, their heads mus
he shaved, that it may be easier, in case o.

The flowers Of earth around thee streWni =

But not to love SO ftrvently.

AFRICAN CASCADE ON THE ORANGE


RIVER.


Having crossed the southern branch,
which at this season is but an inconsderable
creek, we continued to follow the Korannas,
for several miles. through the dense acacia
ferests, while the laundering sound of the
cataract Increased at every step. at length
VIC reached a ridge Of rocks, and found it
necessary to disnount, and follow our guides
OH foot.


1t seemed as if We were now entering the
untrodden vestibulc &C one OF natures most
sublime temples, and the untutored savages
who guided US cvinced by the awe and cir
cumspcction with which they trod, that
they were not altogether uninhuenced by
the gcniHs ioci. They repeatedly requested
me to keep behind, and follow them softly
for the precipiccs were dangerous for the
feet of men; and the sight and sound of the
cataract were so fearful, that they them
selves reg ,rdcd the place with ave, and
ven,urcd but seldom to visit it.


At length the whole Of them halted, and
desired me to DO the same. One of them
stepped forward 10 the brink Of the preci-
bicc, and having looked cautiously over
beckoned me TO advance. did 50, ant
witnessed a curious and striking scene, bu


it was not vet the waterfall. 1t was rapid
formed by almost the whole volume OF the
river, compressed into narrow channel oi
not more than fifty yards i'll breadth, whence


it descended at an angle OF nearly as, and
rushing tumuItuously through black and
crooked chasm among the rocks, OF fright
full depth, escaped in torrent OF foam. My
swarthy guides, although this was unques-
tionably the first time they had ever led a
traveller to view the remarkable scenery OF
their country, cvinced degree OF tact, as
ciceroni as well as natural feeling, Ct the
picturesque. that equally pleased and sur
prised me- Having forewarned me that this
was not vet the waterfall, they now pioneer
ed the way for about a mile farther along
the rocks, some of them keeping near, and
continually cautioning Inc to look to my iect,
as a single false step might precipitate me
into the raging abyss of waters; the tumut oi
which seemed to shake even the solid
rocks around us.


At length we halted, as before, and the
next moment was lead to projecting rock,
where a scene burst upon me, tar surpass-
ing my most sanguine expectations, The
whole water of the river (cXcrpt what es-
canes by the subsidiary channel we had
crossed. and hv similar one Oh the north
side being previously confined to bed OF
scarcely one hundred feet in breadth, de-
sccnds at once in a magnificent cascade oi
full four hundred feet in height. stood
upon a clff nearly level with the top # the
fail, and directly III front of it. The beaus
of the evening sun tell upon the cascade,
and occasoned a most splendid RAINBOW;
while the vapoury msts arising from the
broken roar os the waterfall, and the tunul :
tuous boiling and whirling of the stream be-
low. striving to escape along its deep, dark,
and narrow path, formed altogether COM
bination of beauty and grandeur, such as |
never before witnessed. AS ga2ed on TINS
stnpendous scene, felt as if in dream
The sublmity of nature drowned all apPre-
tensions of danger; and after short pause,
| hastily left the spot where stood to gam
nearer view from a cliff that impended
over the foaming gulf ! had just reached
this station when felt myself grasped all
at once bv four korannas, who simultaneous
! IL seized hold of me by the arms and legs.
nv first impression was that they were So
inr to hurl me over the precipice; but 1t
was a momentarv thought, and it wronged
the friendly savages. They are themselves
timid race; and they were alarmed, lest
nv temerty should lead ME into danger
.rhey hurried me back from the brink, and
then explained their motive, and asked my
forgiveness. ! was not ungrateful Tor their
care, though somewhat annoyed by their Of
ficiousness.-[ 7homhson's Southern 'ftr'cQ'

"May trouble you to inform me what
gentleman that is yonder; he is about torty
years of age, of an elegant appearance, good
figure. we'll dressed, and meet him every
where, He is always aiane whether at the
plav. in the park. in the streets, never yet
saw any body walking with him. lie looks
about with an anxious and scrutnIzing eye
at every one who passes; he does not seem
to be uncomfortable or dissatisfied with him
self. and vet he never smiles. Who is he!
Do pray tell me; and what he is looking tor'


"rhat," replied the friend of whom
made these somwhat rapid inquiries, I" is
the modern Dlogcnes; not that, like the Di-
tsenes OF old, he is looking for man; on the
contrary, a woman is the object OF his search,
a 1d his eyes serve him for a lantern. lie Is
rich, good looking OF agreeable manners,
and excellent understanding; and yet, for
these twenty years, he has been in search OF
a wife. and hitherto in vain. The reason IS,
that he has created chinera, and after
wards set himself to the pursuit GIFT. VIII
tell you his hiitory, and you shall Judge
whether he is not one OF the most singular
men you ever met. >,


"When he was twenty years old, he tel
in love with a young lady, very well educat-
cd. of good family. and possessing thou-
sand excellent qualities. lie paid his au-
dresses to her, was most ass'dnou5 III ms at-
tcntous; asked her parents consent and o'-
/; med Il. Every thing was arranged, "nt =
one evening he happened to be at ball WIN
his intended wife. 1t was then very mucn
the rage to dance the gavotte. Dlogencs
could not perform the gavotte, but ms IN


tended did so admirably. very agfeeaale
Young man asked her to dance with MN;
she did so, and acquitted herself to tue aa-
mratiou of every body present oh we
! following day our friend asked her now she
had passed the night; she confessed among
other things, that she had dreamt OF her
tp?rtner in the gavottc ll'oSches s"t W.
wished her good morning. oroRe OH MS


marriage, and never saw her agaNh'


"A short time afterwards he was smitten
hv vouur lady who had no fortune. but
Who was extremely beautiful and not less
virtuous. He succeeded in making her love
| him also. as he might do, with most women;
and every tla, their mutual affection seemed
| ia increase. When the marriage was near
at hand, he questioned her about the state
of her heart Did you ever love any ono
before me" he was asking her necessarily.
"Neyer," she replied, "you are the first
person that even possessed by heart. iet,
| should tell you, that when was only thir-
teen wears old was very fond OF my cousin,
and used to call him my little husband. =
This was enough for Diogenes; and again he
was off


..Some years elapsed without his making
another attempt. and then he was fascinated
by laly, whose beauties and WI miSht
have induced any man TO overlook some
slight faults. The wedding day was again
fixed, when, coming to visit her one day
unexpectedly, he found her taking pinch
of snuff. He quilted her abruptly, ana went
abroad. He soon returned, and the iirs'
thing he did was to fall in love with SIM
ple mlincr, young, pretty, ana pefiec,'y i,-
exnerienced. He would have put up with
The want Of family and fortune, but one day
he found her telling her fortune with cards.
He quilted her at once, swearing he would
never mite himself to a woman who practc-
ed such supcrs'tiors.


"Since then cannot tell how many en-
o.gements he has made and broken. One
lady was pretty, but coquette; another was
mt a coouette, but she had not grace enough;
onr was affectionatc but jealous; another
gentle but without sense; one had W.T. Out
roo much conceit; another made verses OF
was too fond of dancing, or OF lauShlns' vi


was too prudish, or too volatile or too re- re-
served, In short, Diogenes has had thou


sand passionate engagements, none OF whiIn


have lasted more than eight days. Eas,iy
caught, and as easily loosened again, ne


seeks every where the imaginary ehceie.:e ';


On which he has set his heart. IL is IN VAN


that his friends tell him woman "'lsh'


make an excellent wife, and yet nave n.-


~. .upcr.tition; that lady is not less fa'r


Gov G., having taken one pinch of snuff; that she


nav m love her husband and yet dream OF her


,'ar,rer. n~, and that heart may be perfectly


free although its owner may have called =. a


.a.,s:a sss hs- I..lc husband. BIT his mar Is

information that the several additional con-
victs had been taken down from the hospi-
tai to join them to the party. The two first
who appeared, were, the one, man without

having first been made an Attorney at Cor.
bell, afterwards an Assistant Judge, then
Justice of the Peace, in 1916, was finally con-
demned for forgery on the 5th of April,
1921. His face is deeply marked by the fur
rows sorrow has traced there. 1t will be
recollected, that, after his sentence, he ad-
dressed memorial to his son, in which we're
the following expressions: II have erred.
but have injured no one. / confess that
committed the forgery. How many evils
has this act, perhaps excuseable in itself,
drawn on my head! was, in the month of
November, 1920, denounced to justice, and
this by whom! My heart is torn with sor-
row. No sooner had been arrested than
my Office had been robbed; important
papers, some documents necessary to my
Justification, have all been carried off!


"A separation had been solicited, nv
wife has possessed herself of all had, and
yet had relinquished to her more than /
had received from her mother.


"Taken before the Court of Assizcs. for
forgery, committed 7Dithout intention 10
7crong any one have been sentenced 10 be

"How cruel was the night succeeding this
SENTENCED Love of life. friendship, nature.
relgion--all for me had vanished. / saw
| nothing before me except infamy. Death
was my only resort. did wish to inhict it.
Blessed be that Providence that restrained
my arm! Receive my gratitude, oh ye char
table man, whose cares recalled me to life
againI


"Now. more calm and resigned. shall
yield to my fate, whatever 1t may be. A
victim of fraud, of ingratitude, and of cruel-
ty, have but one wish: may Eliza ever be
happy Let never my son forget the respect
he owes his mother, and let him give few
tears to his unfortunate father!'


Magnon and his companion were ironed
together, in the midst OF an unanimous ap-
plause.


"This is not all--and master the lawyer"
said Boucher, "where is he?" "pTith his
sfectacle8 OIL" said second; he thought
he would persuade them he continued sick"
All Of them hollooed the Lawyer! the Law"
yerl come on lawyer"


At this instant | saw the cause of these
vociferatons. His age is about 35-his
name Rev. Having been received at the
Bar, he resided at Coulommers, and was
likewise condemned fol- the crime of forge
ry. He sorrowfully steps forward, accom-
panied by several officers of the Jail. Death
is painted Oh his visage: he dared not raise
his eyes. "March on" halloo the convicts
round him: "there's no offence: how beau
tiiu will the cravat look on the neck of a
lawver" The wretches! they appreciate
not the sentiments of shame and of repent-
ance. that fill up the soul of the unhappy
Rey


drew near him to offer him some conso-
lation: Sir, he replied in most melancholy
tone. l thank yon most sincerely. l bitterly
suffer for my error loudly call for death,
that it may wrcst me from so many humili-
atoms, and hope that God will dispose Of
me previous to reaching Brest."


The hour of seven had struck: the roll
was called. The convicts placed themselves
in three columns. and their shackles were
inspected. With the assistance of large
ladder, they assembled, two abreast, into long
carts, were they were seated, back to back,
with their feet hanging down. They are
thus to travel three hundred and sixty miles.
lodging at night, in public edifices or barns,
Oh straw.


At five o'clock in the morning an immense
crowd had assembled outside of the gate of
FontaM6ieau and on the highway to see
them Oh their passage: for the departure Of
d DdTty Ol COnNlCtS Is HutiiOeTeu among tnc
solemntios of the suburbs of St. Marceau. A
number of butchers and bakers were stand
ing in their carts with their friends.


This was not altogether an idle curiosity.
have seen mothers who seized this oppor-
tunity to deliver moral lectures to their chill
dren.


The view os this multitude seemed to a,
muse, agreeaby the majority Of the conyicts,
and every Circumstance which could give
6 ound for witticism, was caught by them
with avidity All. with the exception Of
few who endeavoured to hide their faces
bathed in tears, were proud of attracting the
attention of SO many people, and seemed as
if each struggled to distinguish himself by
boldnsss and effrontry.

After having, in the presence of Vidue and
his agents, made The inshection, the slaves
left their ranks, and advanced to the mid
die of the square, where was placed, along
side Of an anvil, large wooden case. Here
we're placed the manacles, which, for time
immemorial, have served in succession to
those whom the laws send into solitude.
When they have, two by two. reached the
anvil, they are married, kneel down, and in
this posture, is applied the crauat, suitable
to the Size of each: (thus they call, in deri-
sion, the iron triangle in which the neck is
securely. 10 the time when these trianges
are closed up, the patients laugh heartily
with their comrades, who lampoon them
But to this succeeds mournful silence, and
a sort of terror, when placed almost under
the repeated blows of the hammer that riv-
cts their irons on the anvil. The least
movement of the head would cause the i'm


mediate crushing of the brains!


Each couple is fastened to a chain COM
posed of from twenty to thirty men; and,
from this instant, they can only move in
mass


\ This operation lasted nearly two hours
j 76 convicts were arranged on Monday. They
( had been divided into three parties. the third


and second composed OF the most turbulent;


in the first had been gathered the most


quiet Each party went to sit on the bench


es, around the square, and the agents with
drew.


No sooner were those wretches freed from
all restraint, than witnessed the most mel
ancholv spectacle. One would readily sup
pose that in the midst of such awful captivi-
ty, with prospect so menacing before him,
man must necessarily give way TO the pun
gency of his sorrows! But alas shall ! say
{ it.-'Ehese unfortunate people, whose lives
are to be divided bctwet4t slavery and lnfa-
my, looked as if they had been assembled on
some joyful occasion. Three only-yes on
| Is three-appeared to be sensible of the ex-
tent Of their misery; they were the only
ones | WAS told, who among the number had
received some education. The others, Ell


ther gave loud expressions Of stupid joy,
attacked each other by lewd conundrums,
or exercised their wits in pleasantries at the
expense of their own ituations.


On sudden. upon the invitation of Bou-
cher, once a hack-d'iver, and now condemn
ed for life, the first party got ready for
promenade; at the signal given by this chief
tain, they all raised with difficulty their
shackles. The weight for each is twelve
pounds, with the exception of Boucher and
/ Grartl, Who are each overloaded @ith "a
hounds. This prccaution has been taken
with them on account of their irequent for
mer escapes FROM jais. An old man among
the rest, rose with difficulty: "Comt: march
+ on" exclaimed youth of about is. placed
alongside of him; "dost thou Sleep already.
old fellow? thou art NOT It the end OF the
Journey" The first column moves on and
20 round; it is soon followed ny the second;
! then the third, which obeys reluctantiy the
iinvitt tion ofthc two first. Let us sit down"
SAID Boucher; and Immediately they sur
rounded chest placed in the midst of the
square. It. was there proposed to play the
siihHer, Ca French play, in which the forfeit
is to receive on the face or elsewhere GER
tain number of blows gwen with an old
! shoc, } when an old military man, agitating
his cane over their heads, caused the whole
troop to move off. Surprised at this step,
the Cahtam replied to my inquiry: "lt is now
| thirty years since ! attended on this rabble.
have led more than thirty thousand souls
to the ealcys, and it is not easy to catch an
old hare like NE. They had grouped chem
selves there, dye see, to take away the files
IN that box, with which, they would, no
tlou5t, have acted upoa their sackles. But
here is my justice of the peace, (shaking his
stick) and if thev move in the least, 1t viii
soon sit them right again" The convicts
then sang, one of them composing an i'm
promptu on their own numbers, whilst the
rest repeated IN chorus their sentiments OH
the harmlessness of the galleys.


When they we're tired to sing and to walk,
they set again OH their benches, where seve-
raj slept. At about five O'clock, an aged
Priest presented himself, accompanied by
two Young men: they had come to assist
those whom their family had forsaken. All
attentivelv listened to the discourse, full OF
auction, of the old man. This venerable
ecclesiastic conversed long time with Du-
bre, young man of %, who committed theft
to procure bread to his mother, who was
thereby thrown into the utmost wretched-
ness. This unfortunate young man, shed
ding torrent of tears, muttcred, with dlth-
Guilty, the following words i was at first
placed in the hospital, and was not to have
gone AS to myself, it matters little but,
alas nv poor mother !--oh, my dear mo-
ther!-she will surely die" ! was moved
into tears. The good Priest told me" this
child must, undoubtedly, have been very
guilty since the law has punished him. How
melancholy is the idea, however, that. in
few davs, he will be as corrupt as the rest
of the wretches with whom he will be asso-
ciated.'' had been under the impression
that Boucher and Girard would have met
the holy man with sarcasms only, but was

pose. might easily be su5dued BY tenderness,
aud overcome by persuasion; and it is no
wonder that he yielded to the entreaties Of
the daughter and permitted her 70 visit her
unhappy mother, though he was under the
necessity Of searching her to prevent her
from being the convcyor Of any Kind of nour-
ishmen.. Several days elapsed, without
any striking alteration in the appearance Of
the unhappy mother. This circumstance
called forth the Keepers astonshmcht So
much, that he began toimaginc the daughter
had contriYed some means OF omding hrs
viigence, and therefore resolved to watch
them, when tho daily meeting took place
He did do, and 5eheld sight that called
forth pity aud adbiraten--an affection
ate daughter was presented 20 his view,
lengthening ont her parents existence by
that nourishmcLt nature had given for
the support of her own offspring, and en-
deayoring to avert the DEGREES of jnsticc, by
the nutritious qualities Of the milk OF tender
ness The humane keeper instantly flew
to her Judge, described the interesting scene
he had beheld, and had the happiness OF
procuring a pardon for the unfortunate OF
fender The Senate wtre 50 struck with
this instance of amiable tenderness, that they
ordered temple to be erected to tilia, pie
IS, on the spot where the prison stood, and
both mother and daughter to be maintaihtd
at the public expense.

full articles.headline: PIRACY AND MURDER.
full articles.article:
. The peculiar circumstances connected
with the case of the Brig Crawford, which
will be developed in the sequel, induced
Chief Justice Marshall to hold special
term of the Federal Court for the Fifth Cir
cult and Eastern District Of Virginia, for the
trial Of the three Spaniards. The Court
was held On the 9Th ult., the most material
with. sses not being present, it was adjourn
ed from day to day, until their arrival from
New York. After they had arrived, four
indictments, one for Piracy and three for
Murder, were sent to the Grand Jury, who
after an examination into the testimony, re-
turned "a true bill" as to each. The three
prisoners, viz: Pepe, otherwise Joseph Hi
iario Cssaris, Couro, otherwise called Jos-
eph Miranda; and Felix, otherwise Felix
Barbeto were all charged in the first indict-
ment with Piracy, and in each of the others.
with the murder of some one OF the persons
who were slaughtered by them. The Court
was adjourned until the 10th, to give the
prisoners time to prepare their defence. The
prisoners having been arraigned pleaded
not guilty to all the indictments.-Mr. Stan
ard, District Attorney for the United States,

full articles.headline: rr-FU GALLEY SLAVE.
full articles.article:
The accompanying is translated from a
livelv description of the departure, for their
ultimate destination, of party OF those IN
dividuals, whom the laws Of France doom to
hard labo, or the galleys. They are from
time to time, turned over from the Courts
which have passed condemnation, to par
ticular iail, whence as soon as suiiicient
number have been gathered, they are sent
n narties. as the one here described, to sea-
norts. where they take the dress and heavy
irons they have to carry during the whoie
term prescribed by law. The former is a
red dress and cap, for those condemned tor
a tenn of wears; and red dress and green
can for the convict for life. Ibis account
heinp characteristic of national character,
under the most distressing circumstances,
and showing the effect of the French code OF
law. as contra distinguished from our own
penal laws, may not be uninteresting to the
philanthropst.


"Some days previeus, it had been amour
ced at Bcetre, that the departure OF the gal
lev slaves, for their respective destinations
would soon take place. At III O'Clock on
Monday, the news was confirmed. those
who were to compose the gang were accord
inpIy assembled together. They descended
ed from their chambers into yard at the
furthest end of the establishment. There was
in readiness the travelling apparel. which
is made of coarse raw linen. Each Of
those designated took his own. Agree ably
To the prison regulations, their heads mus
he shaved, that it may be easier, in case o.

full articles.headline: CLING MOTTO EARTH.
full articles.article:
Cling not to eartli--there's nothing there,
However iov'd-howcvcr fair,
But on its features still must wear


The impress ofmoralty.
The voyagcr on the boundless deep,
Wthln his barque may smile or sleep
But hear him on--he will not weep


To leave its wild uncertainty.
Cling not to eartl--as well we may
Trust Asia's seipent's wanton play,
That Glitters only TO betray


TO death--or else to misery.
Dream not of Fgiendslip--th may be
A word, :; smile, grasp for thee
But wait the hour of need and see


iiut wonder not--ther fallacy.
Think not Of Bcautv-like the rest
1t bears a lus,re on its crest
But short the time ere stands contest


Its falschood-or its iralty.
Then cling no more so fondly on
The flowers Of earth around thee streWni =
They'll do awhile to sport upon,


But not to love SO ftrvently.

full articles.headline:
AFRICAN CASCADE ON THE ORANGE


RIVER.
full articles.article:
AFRICAN CASCADE ON THE ORANGE


RIVER.


Having crossed the southern branch,
which at this season is but an inconsderable
creek, we continued to follow the Korannas,
for several miles. through the dense acacia
ferests, while the laundering sound of the
cataract Increased at every step. at length
VIC reached a ridge Of rocks, and found it
necessary to disnount, and follow our guides
OH foot.


1t seemed as if We were now entering the
untrodden vestibulc &C one OF natures most
sublime temples, and the untutored savages
who guided US cvinced by the awe and cir
cumspcction with which they trod, that
they were not altogether uninhuenced by
the gcniHs ioci. They repeatedly requested
me to keep behind, and follow them softly
for the precipiccs were dangerous for the
feet of men; and the sight and sound of the
cataract were so fearful, that they them
selves reg ,rdcd the place with ave, and
ven,urcd but seldom to visit it.


At length the whole Of them halted, and
desired me to DO the same. One of them
stepped forward 10 the brink Of the preci-
bicc, and having looked cautiously over
beckoned me TO advance. did 50, ant
witnessed a curious and striking scene, bu


it was not vet the waterfall. 1t was rapid
formed by almost the whole volume OF the
river, compressed into narrow channel oi
not more than fifty yards i'll breadth, whence


it descended at an angle OF nearly as, and
rushing tumuItuously through black and
crooked chasm among the rocks, OF fright
full depth, escaped in torrent OF foam. My
swarthy guides, although this was unques-
tionably the first time they had ever led a
traveller to view the remarkable scenery OF
their country, cvinced degree OF tact, as
ciceroni as well as natural feeling, Ct the
picturesque. that equally pleased and sur
prised me- Having forewarned me that this
was not vet the waterfall, they now pioneer
ed the way for about a mile farther along
the rocks, some of them keeping near, and
continually cautioning Inc to look to my iect,
as a single false step might precipitate me
into the raging abyss of waters; the tumut oi
which seemed to shake even the solid
rocks around us.


At length we halted, as before, and the
next moment was lead to projecting rock,
where a scene burst upon me, tar surpass-
ing my most sanguine expectations, The
whole water of the river (cXcrpt what es-
canes by the subsidiary channel we had
crossed. and hv similar one Oh the north
side being previously confined to bed OF
scarcely one hundred feet in breadth, de-
sccnds at once in a magnificent cascade oi
full four hundred feet in height. stood
upon a clff nearly level with the top # the
fail, and directly III front of it. The beaus
of the evening sun tell upon the cascade,
and occasoned a most splendid RAINBOW;
while the vapoury msts arising from the
broken roar os the waterfall, and the tunul :
tuous boiling and whirling of the stream be-
low. striving to escape along its deep, dark,
and narrow path, formed altogether COM
bination of beauty and grandeur, such as |
never before witnessed. AS ga2ed on TINS
stnpendous scene, felt as if in dream
The sublmity of nature drowned all apPre-
tensions of danger; and after short pause,
| hastily left the spot where stood to gam
nearer view from a cliff that impended
over the foaming gulf ! had just reached
this station when felt myself grasped all
at once bv four korannas, who simultaneous
! IL seized hold of me by the arms and legs.
nv first impression was that they were So
inr to hurl me over the precipice; but 1t
was a momentarv thought, and it wronged
the friendly savages. They are themselves
timid race; and they were alarmed, lest
nv temerty should lead ME into danger
.rhey hurried me back from the brink, and
then explained their motive, and asked my
forgiveness. ! was not ungrateful Tor their
care, though somewhat annoyed by their Of
ficiousness.-[ 7homhson's Southern 'ftr'cQ'

full articles.headline: TIE DIFFICULTY EQyER.
full articles.article:
TEE DIFFICULT LoVER.


SKETCH.


"May trouble you to inform me what
gentleman that is yonder; he is about torty
years of age, of an elegant appearance, good
figure. we'll dressed, and meet him every
where, He is always aiane whether at the
plav. in the park. in the streets, never yet
saw any body walking with him. lie looks
about with an anxious and scrutnIzing eye
at every one who passes; he does not seem
to be uncomfortable or dissatisfied with him
self. and vet he never smiles. Who is he!
Do pray tell me; and what he is looking tor'


"rhat," replied the friend of whom
made these somwhat rapid inquiries, I" is
the modern Dlogcnes; not that, like the Di-
tsenes OF old, he is looking for man; on the
contrary, a woman is the object OF his search,
a 1d his eyes serve him for a lantern. lie Is
rich, good looking OF agreeable manners,
and excellent understanding; and yet, for
these twenty years, he has been in search OF
a wife. and hitherto in vain. The reason IS,
that he has created chinera, and after
wards set himself to the pursuit GIFT. VIII
tell you his hiitory, and you shall Judge
whether he is not one OF the most singular
men you ever met. >,


"When he was twenty years old, he tel
in love with a young lady, very well educat-
cd. of good family. and possessing thou-
sand excellent qualities. lie paid his au-
dresses to her, was most ass'dnou5 III ms at-
tcntous; asked her parents consent and o'-
/; med Il. Every thing was arranged, "nt =
one evening he happened to be at ball WIN
his intended wife. 1t was then very mucn
the rage to dance the gavotte. Dlogencs
could not perform the gavotte, but ms IN


tended did so admirably. very agfeeaale
Young man asked her to dance with MN;
she did so, and acquitted herself to tue aa-
mratiou of every body present oh we
! following day our friend asked her now she
had passed the night; she confessed among
other things, that she had dreamt OF her
tp?rtner in the gavottc ll'oSches s"t W.
wished her good morning. oroRe OH MS


marriage, and never saw her agaNh'


"A short time afterwards he was smitten
hv vouur lady who had no fortune. but
Who was extremely beautiful and not less
virtuous. He succeeded in making her love
| him also. as he might do, with most women;
and every tla, their mutual affection seemed
| ia increase. When the marriage was near
at hand, he questioned her about the state
of her heart Did you ever love any ono
before me" he was asking her necessarily.
"Neyer," she replied, "you are the first
person that even possessed by heart. iet,
| should tell you, that when was only thir-
teen wears old was very fond OF my cousin,
and used to call him my little husband. =
This was enough for Diogenes; and again he
was off


..Some years elapsed without his making
another attempt. and then he was fascinated
by laly, whose beauties and WI miSht
have induced any man TO overlook some
slight faults. The wedding day was again
fixed, when, coming to visit her one day
unexpectedly, he found her taking pinch
of snuff. He quilted her abruptly, ana went
abroad. He soon returned, and the iirs'
thing he did was to fall in love with SIM
ple mlincr, young, pretty, ana pefiec,'y i,-
exnerienced. He would have put up with
The want Of family and fortune, but one day
he found her telling her fortune with cards.
He quilted her at once, swearing he would
never mite himself to a woman who practc-
ed such supcrs'tiors.


"Since then cannot tell how many en-
o.gements he has made and broken. One
lady was pretty, but coquette; another was
mt a coouette, but she had not grace enough;
onr was affectionatc but jealous; another
gentle but without sense; one had W.T. Out
roo much conceit; another made verses OF
was too fond of dancing, or OF lauShlns' vi


was too prudish, or too volatile or too re- re-
served, In short, Diogenes has had thou


sand passionate engagements, none OF whiIn


have lasted more than eight days. Eas,iy
caught, and as easily loosened again, ne


seeks every where the imaginary ehceie.:e ';


On which he has set his heart. IL is IN VAN


that his friends tell him woman "'lsh'


make an excellent wife, and yet nave n.-


~. .upcr.tition; that lady is not less fa'r


Gov G., having taken one pinch of snuff; that she


nav m love her husband and yet dream OF her


,'ar,rer. n~, and that heart may be perfectly


free although its owner may have called =. a


.a.,s:a sss hs- I..lc husband. BIT his mar Is

full articles.headline: No. al.
full articles.article:
information that the several additional con-
victs had been taken down from the hospi-
tai to join them to the party. The two first
who appeared, were, the one, man without
education; the other, James Magnon, who,
having first been made an Attorney at Cor.
bell, afterwards an Assistant Judge, then
Justice of the Peace, in 1916, was finally con-
demned for forgery on the 5th of April,
1921. His face is deeply marked by the fur
rows sorrow has traced there. 1t will be
recollected, that, after his sentence, he ad-
dressed memorial to his son, in which we're
the following expressions: II have erred.
but have injured no one. / confess that
committed the forgery. How many evils
has this act, perhaps excuseable in itself,
drawn on my head! was, in the month of
November, 1920, denounced to justice, and
this by whom! My heart is torn with sor-
row. No sooner had been arrested than
my Office had been robbed; important
papers, some documents necessary to my
Justification, have all been carried off!


"A separation had been solicited, nv
wife has possessed herself of all had, and
yet had relinquished to her more than /
had received from her mother.


"Taken before the Court of Assizcs. for
forgery, committed 7Dithout intention 10
7crong any one have been sentenced 10 be
branded, punishment far nor awful than
death itself.


"How cruel was the night succeeding this
SENTENCED Love of life. friendship, nature.
relgion--all for me had vanished. / saw
| nothing before me except infamy. Death
was my only resort. did wish to inhict it.
Blessed be that Providence that restrained
my arm! Receive my gratitude, oh ye char
table man, whose cares recalled me to life
againI


"Now. more calm and resigned. shall
yield to my fate, whatever 1t may be. A
victim of fraud, of ingratitude, and of cruel-
ty, have but one wish: may Eliza ever be
happy Let never my son forget the respect
he owes his mother, and let him give few
tears to his unfortunate father!'


Magnon and his companion were ironed
together, in the midst OF an unanimous ap-
plause.


"This is not all--and master the lawyer"
said Boucher, "where is he?" "pTith his
sfectacle8 OIL" said second; he thought
he would persuade them he continued sick"
All Of them hollooed the Lawyer! the Law"
yerl come on lawyer"


At this instant | saw the cause of these
vociferatons. His age is about 35-his
name Rev. Having been received at the
Bar, he resided at Coulommers, and was
likewise condemned fol- the crime of forge
ry. He sorrowfully steps forward, accom-
panied by several officers of the Jail. Death
is painted Oh his visage: he dared not raise
his eyes. "March on" halloo the convicts
round him: "there's no offence: how beau
tiiu will the cravat look on the neck of a
lawver" The wretches! they appreciate
not the sentiments of shame and of repent-
ance. that fill up the soul of the unhappy
Rey


drew near him to offer him some conso-
lation: Sir, he replied in most melancholy
tone. l thank yon most sincerely. l bitterly
suffer for my error loudly call for death,
that it may wrcst me from so many humili-
atoms, and hope that God will dispose Of
me previous to reaching Brest."


The hour of seven had struck: the roll
was called. The convicts placed themselves
in three columns. and their shackles were
inspected. With the assistance of large
ladder, they assembled, two abreast, into long
carts, were they were seated, back to back,
with their feet hanging down. They are
thus to travel three hundred and sixty miles.
lodging at night, in public edifices or barns,
Oh straw.


At five o'clock in the morning an immense
crowd had assembled outside of the gate of
FontaM6ieau and on the highway to see
them Oh their passage: for the departure Of
d DdTty Ol COnNlCtS Is HutiiOeTeu among tnc
solemntios of the suburbs of St. Marceau. A
number of butchers and bakers were stand
ing in their carts with their friends.


This was not altogether an idle curiosity.
have seen mothers who seized this oppor-
tunity to deliver moral lectures to their chill
dren.


The view os this multitude seemed to a,
muse, agreeaby the majority Of the conyicts,
and every Circumstance which could give
6 ound for witticism, was caught by them
with avidity All. with the exception Of
few who endeavoured to hide their faces
bathed in tears, were proud of attracting the
attention of SO many people, and seemed as
if each struggled to distinguish himself by
boldnsss and effrontry.


PIRACY AND MURDER.

full articles.headline:
From the Ncw-York Mirrcr.
SrANZAS FOR MUSIC.
full articles.article:
From the Ncw-York Mirror


STANZAS FOR MUSIC.
Love twned bower


For Beauty bright,
Sweet Beautys bower Of love!
And she'd his warmest looks OF light,
His purest beams of soft delight,
Around each flower:


A glorious sight
Was Bcauty's bower of Love! .5
Love teckcd the bower


For Beauty's rest,
Sweet Beauty's bower of love
And Innocence was Beauty's guest,
And Hope was there with stars invest
And in a shower


Of visions, blest
Sweet Beauty's bower Of love!
But Falsehood camel


A withering sprite-
To Beauty's bower of Love!
lnazure robe his form of blight
With Friendships smile his face he dlSht--
Truth spoke his name!


And all was night
Round Beauty's bower of Love!

turning gray, and each year it will become
difficult to please the charming sex which
he wishes to find perfect; and which is yet
50 delightful, that man of sense might ca
SLY pardon some slight defects for the innu-
merable good qualities they possess"

II an act OF the 0aSeSt Illumination 10 nave
suffered it to be done by strange hand.
After having, in the presence of Vidue and
his agents, made The inshection, the slaves
left their ranks, and advanced to the mid
die of the square, where was placed, along
side Of an anvil, large wooden case. Here
we're placed the manacles, which, for time
immemorial, have served in succession to
those whom the laws send into solitude.
When they have, two by two. reached the
anvil, they are married, kneel down, and in
this posture, is applied the crauat, suitable
to the Size of each: (thus they call, in deri-
sion, the iron triangle in which the neck is
securely. 10 the time when these trianges
are closed up, the patients laugh heartily
with their comrades, who lampoon them
But to this succeeds mournful silence, and
a sort of terror, when placed almost under
the repeated blows of the hammer that riv-
cts their irons on the anvil. The least
movement of the head would cause the i'm


mediate crushing of the brains!


Each couple is fastened to a chain COM
posed of from twenty to thirty men; and,
from this instant, they can only move in
mass


\ This operation lasted nearly two hours
j 76 convicts were arranged on Monday. They
( had been divided into three parties. the third


and second composed OF the most turbulent;


in the first had been gathered the most


quiet Each party went to sit on the bench


es, around the square, and the agents with
drew.


No sooner were those wretches freed from
all restraint, than witnessed the most mel
ancholv spectacle. One would readily sup
pose that in the midst of such awful captivi-
ty, with prospect so menacing before him,
man must necessarily give way TO the pun
gency of his sorrows! But alas shall ! say
{ it.-'Ehese unfortunate people, whose lives
are to be divided bctwet4t slavery and lnfa-
my, looked as if they had been assembled on
some joyful occasion. Three only-yes on
| Is three-appeared to be sensible of the ex-
tent Of their misery; they were the only
ones | WAS told, who among the number had
received some education. The others, Ell


ther gave loud expressions Of stupid joy,
attacked each other by lewd conundrums,
or exercised their wits in pleasantries at the
expense of their own ituations.


On sudden. upon the invitation of Bou-
cher, once a hack-d'iver, and now condemn
ed for life, the first party got ready for
promenade; at the signal given by this chief
tain, they all raised with difficulty their
shackles. The weight for each is twelve
pounds, with the exception of Boucher and
/ Grartl, Who are each overloaded @ith "a
hounds. This prccaution has been taken
with them on account of their irequent for
mer escapes FROM jais. An old man among
the rest, rose with difficulty: "Comt: march
+ on" exclaimed youth of about is. placed
alongside of him; "dost thou Sleep already.
old fellow? thou art NOT It the end OF the
Journey" The first column moves on and
20 round; it is soon followed ny the second;
! then the third, which obeys reluctantiy the
iinvitt tion ofthc two first. Let us sit down"
SAID Boucher; and Immediately they sur
rounded chest placed in the midst of the
square. It. was there proposed to play the
siihHer, Ca French play, in which the forfeit
is to receive on the face or elsewhere GER
tain number of blows gwen with an old
! shoc, } when an old military man, agitating
his cane over their heads, caused the whole
troop to move off. Surprised at this step,
the Cahtam replied to my inquiry: "lt is now
| thirty years since ! attended on this rabble.
have led more than thirty thousand souls
to the ealcys, and it is not easy to catch an
old hare like NE. They had grouped chem
selves there, dye see, to take away the files
IN that box, with which, they would, no
tlou5t, have acted upoa their sackles. But
here is my justice of the peace, (shaking his
stick) and if thev move in the least, 1t viii
soon sit them right again" The convicts
then sang, one of them composing an i'm
promptu on their own numbers, whilst the
rest repeated IN chorus their sentiments OH
the harmlessness of the galleys.


When they we're tired to sing and to walk,
they set again OH their benches, where seve-
raj slept. At about five O'clock, an aged
Priest presented himself, accompanied by
two Young men: they had come to assist
those whom their family had forsaken. All
attentivelv listened to the discourse, full OF
auction, of the old man. This venerable
ecclesiastic conversed long time with Du-
bre, young man of %, who committed theft
to procure bread to his mother, who was
thereby thrown into the utmost wretched-
ness. This unfortunate young man, shed
ding torrent of tears, muttcred, with dlth-
Guilty, the following words i was at first
placed in the hospital, and was not to have
gone AS to myself, it matters little but,
alas nv poor mother !--oh, my dear mo-
ther!-she will surely die" ! was moved
into tears. The good Priest told me" this
child must, undoubtedly, have been very
guilty since the law has punished him. How
melancholy is the idea, however, that. in
few davs, he will be as corrupt as the rest
of the wretches with whom he will be asso-
ciated.'' had been under the impression
that Boucher and Girard would have met
the holy man with sarcasms only, but was
| curp Sod fo cee thp prp receive him with a SORT

f.sses to have picked up the WORDS ol thc ioiio"-
;nr pleasing Scottish song (hthetto unpuhllsh'
rd1 among the mountains OF Galloway. 1t seems
to have been intended rs u pendant to THE \ ell
low Haired Ladaic"


THE YELLOW HAIRED LAsslE.
In simmer when b!ue.bells blaw saft in the valc
AnJ III, Gul, flower spreads It's breast to the gale,
The vellow.halrcd lassie sits sewing her seam,
Beneath the green willow that waves oer 'hc


stream.


wi, melody melting mar salt than hntc,
she sings, while the birds in the branches sit


mute;


yon high rugged rock is sac charmed VII her


strain,


That, cnraptuled, it echoes the theme back


again.


At evening, when dcwdrops begin to distll,
And mixed wi the breeze is the sound o ilk rlli
1be vellow haired lassic will stcaltrae the thrang,
Enjoying sail silence the woodlands anang
The moon, as she rises. looks blithe in her face,
Her shadow the wide-sprcadns waters embrace
Amazed vi SIC beauty, awhile they would sia5
And murmur farewell" as they glide on thcii


way.


o. tell me, yc winds, that We round her at " ~
And talk frae her lips O. sweet kisses your I'll,
The secrets yc learn as ye walltun alang,
